title: Sports-no-CBC
text:
Canada's Aaron Brown and Andre De Grasse took care of business at the track and field world championships on Friday.

The 100-metre medal hopefuls each earned automatic entry into the semifinals after placing second during their respective heats in Doha, Qatar.

WATCH | De Grasse eases into semis:

Andre De Grasse finishes second to American Justin Gatlin in the second heat of the men's 100m event in Doha, Qatar. 3:23

Toronto's Brown, the reigning national champion, ran 10.16 seconds in the first heat before De Grasse, of Markham, Ont., clocked in at 10.13 in the second.

The Canadians will run in the semifinal on Saturday at 11:45 a.m. ET, with the final scheduled for 3:15 p.m. ET.

CBC Sports has exclusive live coverage of the 2019 World Track & Field Championships from Sept. 27-Oct. 6. Visit the stream and broadcast schedule , You can also add the complete event schedule to your calendar.

WATCH | Brown's second-place finish sends him to semis:

Toronto's Aaron Brown finishes second in the first heat of the men's 100m event in Doha, Qatar. 3:20

In the first major international race without retired sprint star Usain Bolt since 2007, American Christian Coleman maintained his status as the favourite after winning his heat with the day's best time at 9.98. Coleman, 23, was the only sprinter to break the 10-second mark.

Coleman entered the worlds amid some controversy after missing three drug tests within one year, which is supposed to carry the same penalty as a positive result. However, a technicality related to the dates of the missed tests absolved the Atlanta native and allowed him to compete at worlds.

Fellow American Justin Gatlin — the 37-year-old reigning world champion — also eased his way through at 10.06.

South Africa's Akani Simbine also impressed after clocking in at 10.01 seconds.

The top three sprinters in each heat, plus the next six fastest, all qualify for the semifinals.

description: Canada's Aaron Brown and Andre De Grasse took care of business at the track and field world championships on Friday. The 100-metre medal hopefuls each earned automatic entry into Saturday's semifinals after placing second during their respective heats in Doha, Qatar.
